Name: Eaton Corporation
Name_1: Local shed companies taking advantage of boom in business spurred by pandemic - Salisbury Post
Text_1:
Local shed companies taking advantage of boom in business spurred by pandemic Published 12:00 am Sunday February 14 2021

SALISBURY ‚Äî Sitting in his office on West Innes Street Conrad Eaton is surrounded by sheds.

That‚Äôs how it‚Äôs been for most of his life.

When he was just 14 years old he started working alongside his younger brother Merritt at their father‚Äôs shed and storage business hammering together huts and tearing shingles off roofs. Growing up in a Mennonite-Baptist household Conrad‚Äôs days were structured. He didn‚Äôt watch TV or play video games. Even if his parents had allowed it there wouldn‚Äôt have been much time.

‚ÄúI would go to work all day and come home and do school at night and then have chores on top of that‚Äù Conrad said. ‚ÄúWe were always very busy.‚Äù

Conrad continued to work for his father‚Äôs company Liberty Storage Solutions until he was 29. That‚Äôs when he decided to step out on his own and build his own shed business.

‚ÄúWhen I initially told my dad he was taken back because it was hard for him‚Äù Conrad said. ‚ÄúI used to work in his business. So I went from being involved in his business to actually being a competitor.‚Äù

Conrad‚Äôs father Bobby Eaton soon came to terms with the move and has been supportive of his son‚Äôs venture which is named in part to honor him.

‚ÄúThe reason I named my business Legacy Shed Company is to build a legacy in our community a legacy of hard work and dedication as well as of integrity and quality‚Äù Conrad said. ‚ÄúAlso to continue my dad‚Äôs legacy. My dad has always been a hard worker.‚Äù

Bobby always taught Conrad and Merritt along with their six other siblings how to grow a business which is what Conrad has been doing since he opened Legacy Shed Company in late 2019.

After starting with just a few employees Conrad has grown his team to around 30 people. In 2020 Legacy surpassed $2 million in sales and was building $150000 worth in units per week as the demand for sheds skyrocketed during the COVID-19 pandemic. The company now sells and delivers sheds in North and South Carolina Georgia and even Alabama.

‚ÄúShed sales have shot through the roof‚Äù Conrad said. ‚ÄúAcross the industry we‚Äôve seen record sales. Basically factories are unable to keep up. Last year we were as far as eight weeks behind on orders. It‚Äôs a rapidly growing industry.‚Äù

The shed business has been expanding for years Conrad said but the recent growth has been spurred mainly by the COVID-19 pandemic.

‚ÄúA lot of people have been forced to be at home. Now they‚Äôre cleaning out their garage and doing garden work and doing the ‚Äòdaddy do‚Äô lists and finally getting stuff done‚Äù Conrad said. ‚ÄúAnd then of course you have people buying them as little office spaces because now people have to work from home. They‚Äôre no longer going into their business so they buy a little building and finish it out not as living quarters but as a little man cave or to get out of the house and do office work quietly and alone away from the kids.‚Äù

The high demand for sheds has allowed Conrad‚Äôs company to expand while competing against both his father‚Äôs business and the company started by his brother Merritt called Heritage Shed Company and also located in Salisbury.

‚ÄúWe‚Äôre all actually competitors but we get along great‚Äù Conrad said. ‚ÄúThere‚Äôs more than enough to go around. It‚Äôs an interesting family dynamic because we‚Äôre all competitive but in a good way. We don‚Äôt avoid talking about business when we‚Äôre all together no matter what we do. It‚Äôs always a good thing to be like that to where we aren‚Äôt fighting each other.‚Äù

The Eatons aren‚Äôt just competing with family. There are dozens of shed companies in and around Rowan County that are taking advantage of the shed boom including Sheds by Design.

Started by Silas Bowling in late 2018 Sheds by Design is a small family-owned operation located in Cleveland. Bowling learned how to build sheds originally while working for Liberty Storage Solutions and before eventually his own business.

The first six months of owning his own shed company were difficult Bowling said. Now that the industry is booming so is his business.

Bowling said he prides himself on being able to build and deliver custom sheds quickly which has been more difficult as of late due to supply chain issues and sky-high material prices driven up by the pandemic.

Although lumber prices have dropped from hitting a record settlement of $928.20 per 1000 board feet on Sept. 1 Bowling said that accessibility to lumber is still an issue.

‚ÄúThey say one of the biggest risks is not necessarily the price I‚Äôm paying for lumber but the lack of supply‚Äù Bowling said.

Those same issues have slowed progress in Conrad‚Äôs shed-building facility in Pickens South Carolina which is run by his business partner and cousin. The major dilemma for Legacy Conrad said is keeping shed prices affordable despite the high cost of lumber.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs about still trying to be affordable as a company and profitable and having a good product‚Äù Conrad said. ‚ÄúIt has been very very stressful.‚Äù

Conrad estimated that up to 90% of his sheds are purchased on rent-to-own payment plans while Bowling said that about 40% of his customers are on rental contracts.

Affordability and quality are the attributes that Conrad has tried to instill in his business which he said he models after a local Salisbury restaurant.

‚ÄúLegacy is trying to be like Hap‚Äôs‚Äù Conrad said. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre trying to serve hotdogs and burgers and do a really good job to where people will line up out of the door for a good product. We don‚Äôt offer as many options as far as fancy goes but we offer a superior quality and we‚Äôre trying to stay in our lane as far as what we offer.‚Äù

Like Hap‚Äôs Grill Conrad hopes that the shed boom continues and that customers will continue to line up for years to come.

Editor‚Äôs Note: This story has been updated to correctly reflect the name of a person pictured.
Name_2: Just like that North Fayette family grows from one child to five
Name_3: The show must go on: High school performing arts manage uncertainty of COVID-19
Text_3:
When Eliana Mascarenas and her fellow Greeley Central cast and crew mates arrive for musical rehearsal each night they confront a very different vibe and atmosphere in the auditorium from years past.

Musical productions are social shows; friendly and grand productions featuring full-cast numbers with intricate choreography and supported by a rousing orchestra. But this year Greeley Central‚Äôs production is more introverted because of COVID-19.

The students many of whom are good friends with a deep interest in theater and the performing arts sign in when they arrive for rehearsals so show leaders can chart attendance in case contact tracing is needed. The young performers wear masks and keep their distance while waiting for their turn on stage during rehearsals. They use hand sanitizer frequently and take breaks to wash their hands.

Since late January the Greeley Central cast and crew has been preparing to perform ‚ÄúThe 25th Annual Putnam County Spelling Bee‚Äù a COVID-19 friendly production scheduled to run in mid-April. Released in 2005 the spelling bee musical is the story of several socially awkward youngsters finding joy heartache and purpose in competing in the regional spelling bee according to a synopsis on www.playbill.com.

‚ÄúMy freshman-year me would have never imagined doing our senior year show this way‚Äù said Mascarenas who has a lead in the role Miss Rona Lisa Peretti former spelling bee champion turned moderator. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs better than nothing. Since freshman year it‚Äôs where I see my friends and the thought of not having that for my senior year would‚Äôve been heartbreaking. We can‚Äôt have all of the fun we used to have.‚Äù

Greeley Central is planning six live performances April 14-17. But even as rehearsals are well underway the future of Central‚Äôs production remains uncertain. The pandemic closed last year‚Äôs musical weeks before opening night.

In scholastic performing arts this year COVID-19 is the conductor director and choreographer of productions from musicals and plays to band and choral concerts. Students and staff involved with local high school shows which are integral components of the school experience similar to athletics want nothing more than to be seen live in a traditional format.

Yet they understand they perform at the mercy of a virus and the shows won‚Äôt look as they have in the past.

‚ÄúI think the word performing is in performing arts for a reason‚Äù Eaton High School band director Logan Doddridge said. ‚ÄúWe can‚Äôt have performances as we normally do and that is taking the heart out of the arts and we‚Äôve re-invented ourselves. We‚Äôre fighting and doing everything we can to have a performance. I think artists around the world and musicians are struggling and I guess that lights the fire even more.‚Äù

A COVID FRIENDLY SHOW

Mascarenas and fellow senior Armando Flores Montenegro are grateful to have Putnam County this year for all of the changes from the norm. As recently as late in the first semester they didn‚Äôt know if they‚Äôd get another chance to perform in a musical at Central.

They were in the cast of last year‚Äôs production of the comedy ‚ÄúSomething Rotten‚Äù before spring activities were shut down. The disappointment surrounding the cancellation had an extra layer for the Central students. The school was one of two high schools nationwide to earn the amateur rights to perform the show.

The 17-year-old Flores Montenegro who shares the role of William Barfee in Putnam County said the experience this year has been stressful at times given the limitations and needed protocols. But he said he expects the production to be ‚Äúa good compromise‚Äù rather than enduring another year without a musical production.

‚ÄúI want to show Central is putting on some sort of arts and not succumbing to what the virus is forcing us to do‚Äù Flores Montenegro said. ‚ÄúThis feels like we can do this and be safe.‚Äù

Safety was key in the minds of director Brian Humphrey and choreographer and arts magnet coordinator Christy O‚ÄôConnell-Black in figuring out how to put on a musical in a pandemic.

Greeley-Evans School District 6 Assistant Superintendent of Secondary Schools Anthony Asmus said the district remains ‚Äúcautious but extremely excited‚Äù with the improvement of state and county data surrounding the spread of COVID-19. Earlier this month Weld County moved to a more open yellow status on the state‚Äôs COVID-19 dial. The effect then on shows such as ‚ÄúThe 25th Annual Putnam County Spelling Bee‚Äù could be significant.

Asmus said there was a concern among district officials about the fate of performing arts events when the county remained on red status earlier this year. Given the improvement Asmus said at this point the district will allow two parents per student performing to attend the shows which is not an option the district has had since the start of the school year.

Students in drama choir and band must continue to follow the guidelines of 6-feet on social distancing.

‚ÄúIt is important to District 6 to try as best we can to be as safe as we can be to provide opportunities for our students to feel part of the school culture‚Äù Asmus said. ‚ÄúIt would be easy to shut everything down. We want to keep as much of the student experience as normal as possible during the pandemic.‚Äù

‚ÄúThe 25th Annual Putnam County Spelling Bee‚Äù allows the Greeley Central performers to maintain a sense of normality. O‚ÄôConnell-Black said the show features only nine roles. About 30 Central students auditioned and 20 were cast to allow for more participation while adhering to safety protocols. And because the show is about a spelling bee students have to step forward and away from other performers to sing or speak their parts.

The one-act show requires minimal choreography and ‚Äúzero touching‚Äù O‚ÄôConnell-Black said with a running time of about 90 minutes.

‚ÄúIt was the COVID-friendliest show we could come up with‚Äù she said adding the show also lends a right tone for the times. ‚ÄúWe wanted something light and comedic.‚Äù

THE BANDS PLAYS ON

After winning a state championship in 2019 the Eaton High School Marching Band was out of competition for the majority of the fall 2020 season.

Director Logan Doddridge who has overseen a growth spurt in the band program since his arrival nearly eight years ago wanted to maintain the momentum from the state victory. Eaton gathered with a couple other Weld County bands to create competitions.

With planning the Eaton marching band played on through the fall as the school‚Äôs football team won a state title. Doddridge said he and the students also wanted a normal season and they worked hard to create guidelines and follow them.

The Eaton concert and jazz bands also continue with adjustments. The robust Eaton band program has five bands: two concert bands two jazz bands and a marching band. The jazz and concert bands are preparing for concerts in late February and early March.

‚ÄúThe main word is distance‚Äù Doddridge said. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôll do everything we can to keep it alive. The main priority is to keep everyone safe.‚Äù

Doddridge said band parents made masks for the musicians to use when they play inside. Bell covers are used on the brass and woodwind instruments ‚Äî such as the clarinets saxophones trumpets trombones French horns and tubas ‚Äî to prevent the spread of airborne droplets but with minimal effect on the collective sound.

‚ÄúThe kids have gotten used to playing with them and now they sound great‚Äù Doddridge said.

At times bands use the high school gymnasium to rehearse in a bigger space. When practicing in the band room the area is rearranged as necessary to allow and create social distancing Doddridge said.

The musicians also practice outside as the weather permits including the concert and jazz bands. The winter concert in December was an online virtual event.

‚ÄúWe‚Äôve had to kind of reinvent what a concert is‚Äù Doddridge said. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôve had to reinvent that and go outside. The challenges there are to get the right audio equipment and to have the kids be comfortable outside‚Äù in an less familiar environment for some of the musicians.

GREELEY WEST GOING DIGITAL

Instead of staging a musical production this year Greeley West will try a different approach. Theater teacher and director of theater Peggy Freemole and her students are going with an all-digital production.

The school will perform ‚ÄúA Killer Party‚Äù a digital murder mystery created during the pandemic for the unusual times. The show has 20 student actors with eight leads and a full ensemble.

‚ÄúThey‚Äôre learning something new and we‚Äôre making it work‚Äù Freemole said of the students. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs difficult. It‚Äôs been a difficult time for them.‚Äù

For ‚ÄúA Killer Party‚Äù the student performers are recording their parts and the show will be mixed and edited with the goal of an April release date. But given the unfamiliarity of the digital process Freemole said she does not know how the show will be released. Freemole suggested they might attempt to host viewing parties and maybe outside depending on COVID-19 restrictions.

Freemole and the students are receiving assistance from high school choir teacher Angela Slaughter orchestra director Thomas Nugent and band director Chet Arthur. She said Slaughter worked with students outside on singing and Nugent led an orchestra recording music from the show. Slaughter and Nugent are pitching in to help Freemole on the technical elements of gathering and assembling the vocal and instrumental components.

‚ÄúWe‚Äôre all working together‚Äù Freemole added. ‚ÄúWith this musical a lot of it is technology that is new to me. They (Slaughter and Nugent) are running with that.‚Äù

Like at Greeley Central the Greeley West students didn‚Äôt get a chance to put on their spring musical in 2020. They also lost out on a fall play.

The school planned a ‚Äúlarge-scale production‚Äù of the musical ‚ÄúMatilda‚Äù Freemole said. Costumes were completed for ‚ÄúMatilda‚Äù and sets remained on stage as of earlier this year.

Freemole arrived at Greeley West in 1988 and has annually been involved with the production of at least two shows a year ‚Äî a fall play and a musical. A group of 15 theater students also missed the chance on a trip to Edinburgh Scotland in August. They were going to perform a musical review at The Edinbugh Festival Fringe which is touted as the world‚Äôs largest arts festival.

‚ÄúI feel sorry for the kids‚Äù Freemole said of the performing arts students. ‚ÄúI have such an incredibly talented senior class and it‚Äôs crazy. We‚Äôre good. We‚Äôre OK but they‚Äôre fully aware of what they lost.‚Äù
Name_4: HAL aims to drive up indigenised content of LCA Tejas
Text_4: "Even when we talk about LCA and for that matter our rotary wings the LUH and LCH there are many items we still have to get from outside because off-the-shelf I am not getting those items in India. HAL cannot make all the items that are required" he said.

Name: eBay
Name_1: PSA: eBay might not let you sell items without a bank account starting Valentine's Day
Text_1:
In 2002 eBay bought PayPal for $1.5 billion turning it into the way you‚Äôd buy and get paid for items you sell on the ginormous auction site. But the once-happy couple has been breaking up for years ‚Äî and on Valentine‚Äôs Day some sellers may no longer be able to sell items on eBay at all without connecting an old-school bank account instead.

This morning I received a final warning that I would need to add a bank account by February 14th or else ‚Äúyour ability to revise or relist existing listings or create new listings will be disabled.‚Äù

eBay tells The Verge this isn‚Äôt the deadline for every seller ‚Äî it‚Äôs rolling out in phases and a quick scan of the web shows it‚Äôs been going on for at least a couple years. This isn‚Äôt the final phase either as eBay tells us the rollout won‚Äôt be complete until 2022. But I suspect it‚Äôs moving fast: I got this message despite rarely ever selling items on eBay and company tells me the ‚Äúmajority of sellers‚Äù will have eBay-managed payments by the end of this year.

Digging up a bank account and plugging it into your profile may not be the only annoyance here by the way. You could be waiting a lot longer for your money as eBay‚Äôs managed payments site points out:

Three to six business days is a long time to theoretically wait for money that could have instantly popped into your PayPal. (That said my last eBay sale didn‚Äôt immediately release my funds to PayPal either. Shrug emoji.)

On the plus side eBay says most sellers should actually pay lower fees than before and provides a variety of case studies at this page ‚Äî but it‚Äôs not like eBay‚Äôs really passing along the savings. Previously eBay would typically take a 10 percent cut and PayPal would take a 2.9 percent cut for a total of 12.9 percent of your take; now eBay will take a 12.35 percent cut in the same situations.
Name_2: eBay's Authentique Candle Smells Like New Sneakers
Text_2:
Didn‚Äôt get your other half a brand new pair of kicks for Valentine‚Äôs Day? Well there‚Äôs no need to worry as eBay has announced the launch of its new scented candle Authentique.

With scents of warm pebbled leather glue EVA foam and an accenting touch of cotton blossom Authentique is designed to smell just like a brand new pair of box-fresh sneakers. That smell you get from unboxing a new pair of shoes can now fill your home with its intoxicatingly bad-but-good aroma enticing the thrill of getting your hands on a new pair.

The small-batch production of candles means that this is a truly limited piece of eBay memorabilia coming packaged in a sneaker box inspired design and sporting a label that‚Äôs reminiscent of a shoe box‚Äôs label. On the tag you‚Äôll find information such as its 35-hour burn time and net weight of 220g.

Alongside the launch of its Authentique candle eBay has expanded its Authenticity Guarantee offering to all new Nike and adidas sneakers worth $100 USD or more. The eBay Authentique candle is dropping on a dedicated website this Valentine‚Äôs Day and costs $25 USD.

For more home scents check out the latest from Cremate.
Name_3: A GUIDE TO THE BEST FASHION RESALE SITES
Text_3:
The way in which luxury fashion is being consumed has radically changed mainly due to the fact that its clientele has also shifted. Our generation prefers online shopping for sold out rare pieces any day over waiting for the traditional in-store seasonal collection sales. This has allowed us more freedom and accessibility as a not only a buyer but also as a seller. In fact resale culture has become an entity of its own which operates on an extremely fast-paced basis. Let‚Äôs be real not many of us are looking to buy life-long investment pieces anymore. Instead we‚Äôre all interested in a circular economy where an item is bought for a short amount of time to then be re-sold to someone else. Out with old and in with the new. So we have rounded six of the best sites to shop that sold-out piece you‚Äôve been obsessing over.

1-eBay

Though eBay may not immediately make you think of high fashion and streetwear it is still an essential destination for all fashion fanatics. Acting as a founding father for all resale websites eBay holds some of the best hidden gems. Though there is quite a bit of filtering to be done to determine fakes from reals as of last year eBay has launched a sneaker authentication program. The way it works is quite simple. As a seller you can ship your sneakers to a third party authentication expert who will rigorously check your shoes. Once they‚Äôve been approved the shoes will receive an official eBay hashtag ensuring its authenticity to any potential buyer. So from certified YEEZY listings to vintage Margiela jackets you can find anything on eBay with the right key terms.
Name_4: Dropshipping: How to use Amazon and eBay to become your own boss
Text_4:
Maybe you've seen videos circulating online of people who have quit their corporate jobs to pursue a dream of entrepreneurial success. One of the most popular forms nowadays revolves around a concept in e-commerce known as dropshipping.

Dropshipping is a business model that allows entrepreneurs to sell products to their customers without ever having to stock inventory themselves. In this growing niche the retailer is a middleman between buyer and supplier.

There are many advantages to this method. According to a dropshipping explainer from e-commerce company Shopify  the model allows entrepreneurs to take more risks on products. Because there is no overhead for storing the product retailers can experiment with different products and product lines. Retailers are also not tied to a physical location meaning they can sell products to any market in the world so long as they can find a supplier who can ship to that market.

However there are also several pitfalls. The barrier to entry is quite low meaning that anyone with enough money saved up can enter the market increasing competition and making it harder to stand out. The margins are also low. Because the retailer does not store nor own the product they have to pay the third party collecting a fraction of the selling price.

Tom Cormier or eCom Tom as he is known is the co-founder of Dropshipping University. Cormier who graduated with a degree in chemical engineering in 2016 was looking for a way to earn some extra money along with his paycheck. "I was like I want some money on the side. And I think I always just had the idea that I never wanted to work full time for a job ever."

Cormier's journey into dropshipping started with re-selling old video games and eventually lead to reselling cell phones ‚Äî until an exchange went south and Cormier was robbed. The experience made Tom reconsider how he would earn extra money.
Name_5: Sellers Choice Awards 2021: Merchants Rate Top Online Marketplaces
Text_5:
Welcome to the 12th annual EcommerceBytes Sellers Choice Awards. Each year we invite sellers to rate and review the marketplaces on which they sell and they use the opportunity to tell companies (and each other) what‚Äôs working and what isn‚Äôt.

As in past years we let readers nominate their top choices and then opened up the voting to the top 10 nominated venues.

Readers rated the finalists in four key areas ‚Äì profitability customer service communication and ease of use. Respondents were also asked how likely they were to recommend each marketplace as a selling venue to a friend or colleague.

As they do every year sellers pointed to specific policies and practices that affected them.

There was great diversity of sellers responding. Some were newbies or low-volume; others noted they were longtime pros. Some were artisans and some used fulfillment services.

The Results



eBay again topped the list this year overall followed by Bonanza and Ruby Lane. The rankings take into account four key criteria ‚Äì profitability customer service communication and ease of use.

Coming in fourth place was Etsy followed by Mercari and Poshmark. Amazon narrowly squeaked ahead of eCrater with Craigslist and Facebook coming in ninth and tenth place respectively.

eBay took the top spot for Profitability again this year and it also placed first in Ease of use. Bonanza took top spots for Customer Service and Communication and it also was the top most recommended marketplace.

With more people shopping online due to the coronavirus ecommerce should have been the rising tide that lifted all boats in 2020. But there were fewer outright mentions of the effects of COVID-19 than we had expected.

Some sellers noted that they had benefitted from extra traffic to marketplaces but it also left them vulnerable to claims of late delivery especially during the holiday shopping period when some marketplaces decided the fate of Item Not Received claims. Despite getting packages into the mail on time it was the seller not the carrier that ended up taking losses when items weren‚Äôt delivered on time some sellers said.

The top nominated venues were diverse from traditional marketplaces like eBay and Amazon; to niche sites; to classifieds site Craigslist; to social platforms like Facebook. Some of the finalists were large publicly traded companies; others were tiny versions.

In reading through sellers reviews we picked up on three attitudes towards marketplaces. First there were the venues where sellers could list with little investment in time or money and what sales they got were quite satisfactory. Those were the ‚Äúit is what it is‚Äù venues.

Then there were the ‚Äúmega platforms‚Äù where some sellers were quite satisfied due to the volume of sales but others bristled due to a feeling that the companies had stacked the deck against the sellers. It went beyond the typical complaints of ‚Äúnickle-and-diming‚Äù fees to practices such as charging a commission fee on shipping and sales tax which sellers felt were wrong.

And then there were marketplaces where sellers felt at home and enjoyed selling but yearned for more traffic and sales. Those venues offered autonomy or an attractive fee structure and sellers urged those venues to advertise more to fulfill their potential.

You can read more about these issues in the individual findings for each marketplace. Next up ‚Äì rankings and how they break down.

How It Breaks Down ‚Äì Profitability

We asked sellers ‚ÄúHow would you rate your profitability as a seller on (marketplace name)?‚Äù eBay topped the list for Profitability followed by Etsy Mercari Craigslist and Facebook.

How It Breaks Down ‚Äì Customer Service

We asked sellers ‚ÄúHow would you rate the customer service (marketplace name) provides to sellers?‚Äù Bonanza topped the list for Customer Service followed by Ruby Lane eBay Etsy and Poshmark.

How It Breaks Down ‚Äì Communication

We asked sellers ‚ÄúHow would you rate (marketplace name)‚Äôs communication with you as a seller?‚Äù Bonanza topped the list for Communication followed by Ruby Lane eBay Poshmark and Etsy.

How It Breaks Down ‚Äì Ease of Use

We asked sellers ‚ÄúHow would you rate (marketplace name)‚Äôs ease of use as a seller?‚Äù eBay topped the list for Ease of Use followed by Bonanza Etsy Mercari and Craigslist.

How It Breaks Down ‚Äì Recommended Selling Venue

We asked sellers ‚ÄúHow likely are you to recommend (marketplace name) as a Selling venue to a friend or colleague? Bonanza scored highest on Recommended Selling Venue followed by Mercari Etsy eBay and Ruby Lane.

Comments: Insider Information

With thousands of responses it‚Äôs impossible to include every comment each marketplace received but we include the most representative comments and the ones most interesting or useful to readers. Note that the number of comments left for a marketplace doesn‚Äôt necessarily indicate its placement in the rankings

Comments are included on the individual marketplace rating pages.

Individual Online Marketplace Ratings

You can find each marketplace with the results of the Sellers Choice survey on the following pages.

Page 1 Sellers Choice Marketplace Ratings: eBay

Page 2 Sellers Choice Marketplace Ratings: Bonanza

Page 3 Sellers Choice Marketplace Ratings: Ruby Lane

Page 4 Sellers Choice Marketplace Ratings: Etsy

Page 5 Sellers Choice Marketplace Ratings: Mercari

Page 6 Sellers Choice Marketplace Ratings: Poshmark

Page 7 Sellers Choice Marketplace Ratings: Amazon

Page 8 Sellers Choice Marketplace Ratings: eCrater

Page 9 Sellers Choice Marketplace Ratings: Craigslist

Page 10 Sellers Choice Marketplace Ratings: Facebook

Leave Your Comments about the Sellers Choice Results

We thank all readers who took the time to rate the marketplaces. If you have comments about the Sellers Choice Awards please feel free to post them below.

Update 2/14/2021: Check out the EcommerceBytes Blog for more commentary.

Name: Ecolab
Name_1: Recykal Becomes 1st member from India for WEF‚Äôs The Circulars Accelerator Programme 2021
Text_1:
Recykal has been selected as the 1st Indian company to be a cohort member for the World Economic Forum(WEF)‚Äôs Circulars Accelerator Programme 2021. The company has been selected for the category ‚ÄòRecovering Value‚Äô. This is Circulars Accelerator‚Äôs 1st cohort of leading circular innovators from around the world.

i.The 6 month program is headed by Accenture in partnership with Anglo American Ecolab and Schneider Electric and in collaboration with UpLink and the World Economic Forum(WEF).

ii.The programme will connect 17 circular economy entrepreneurs to upgrade the disruptive cross-sector value chain innovation.

iii.The other category of the programme include Transforming Consumption & Innovating Products & Production.

Click here to know about other members

Circulars Accelerator Program

Transition

The Circulars the world‚Äôs premier circular economy awards has now been transitioned to a Circulars Accelerator program.

What Happens in the Program?

i.It connects innovators and entrepreneurs with industry leaders and circular experts who provide targeted mentorship.

ii.The innovators will receive deep expertise through the key program elements including workshops among others.

iii.It also supports innovators to develop plans to improve their circular solutions championed and guided by cross-industry leaders.

Gist about Recykal:

i.It is India‚Äôs first digital waste-commerce (w-commerce) company that connects waste generators with waste processors and recyclers and brand owners to solve some of the biggest challenges faced by the industry including demand-supply mismatch and lack of transparency and traceability

ii.It is an end-to-end digital solutions provider that ensures high rates of waste collection recycling and facilitates transactions for all stakeholders across India‚Äôs waste management and recycling value chain.

This provides an opportunity to the circular economy to ensure that more materials are being entered in the recycling streams and less moving to landfills.

iii.The company through its digital platforms channels more than 10000 tonnes of recyclables every month and plans to increase it to 2 million tonnes of plastic annually by 2025.

Recent Related News:

On September 14 2020 India & Afghanistan were elected as Members of the United Nations (UN) Commission on Status of Women a body of the Economic and Social Council (ECOSOC). The Commission on the Status of Women is a UN organ promoting gender equality and the empowerment of women.

Name_1: 10 Things Fans Never Knew About EA's Star Wars: Rise To Power

Name_2: Earnings calendar for the week of February 15
Text_2:
The benchmark indexes mostly stayed on an upward trajectory before edging down towards the end of the week indicating that the excitement surrounding the stimulus bill and vaccination drive has probably slowed down.

Setting a new record the Dow Jones Industrial Average remained above the psychologically significant 31000-mark but ended Thursday‚Äôs session lower. Following a similar pattern the S&P 500 Index made modest gains and reached a new peak mid-week before paring a part of the gains in the following session.

Meanwhile COVID-related filings for unemployment benefit remained elevated last week resulting in first-time claims of about 793000 which was above economists‚Äô prediction.

Elsewhere Israel-based online marketplace Fiverr acquired New York-headquartered creative network Working not Working for an undisclosed amount. Hormel Foods the company behind several popular food brands this week gobbled up Kraft Heinz Company‚Äôs snack nut portfolio Planters in a deal worth $3.4 billion. In another major deal gaming giant Electronic Arts agreed to buy Glu Mobile for $2.1 billion.

With the earnings season entering the final phase the coming week will be a lean period for Wall Street in terms of financial releases. Drug store chain CVS Health Co. which is set for a mass COVID vaccination drive is schedule to unveil fourth-quarter numbers on February 16 before the opening bell. The only other major companies reporting in the holiday-shortened week are Analog Devices and Baidu are ‚Äì February 17. The typically busy Thursday will see muted activity.

Investors‚Äô attention was mostly focused on Coca-Cola and PepsiCo this week amid speculations about their fiscal performance in the final months of 2020 after staying resilient to the pandemic thus far. The soft drink giants published stronger-than-expected earnings mid-week.

In a sign that Canadian cannabis firms have a long way to go before achieving sustainable growth market leader Canopy Growth Tuesday reported a wider loss for the most recent quarter. Aurora Cannabis which unveiled results on Thursday also reported a loss.

The other major firms to have published earnings in the last few days include Cisco and Twitter ‚Äì Thursday. General Motors reported Wednesday and the next day Walt Disney came out with a surprise profit for the first quarter.

Key Earnings to Watch

Monday: Recruit Holdings BHP Group and Contact Energy

Tuesday: CVS Health Corp Autonation Agilent Technologies iBio Inc. Boyd Gaming Corp. Lattice Semiconductor Corp. and Exact Sciences Corp

Wednesday: Akzo Nobel Charles River Laboratories Shopify Analog Devices Hilton Worldwide Holdings Garmin Occidental Petroleum Twilio Brightcove QuickLogic IQIYI Domino‚Äôs Pizza and Baidu

Name_3: PCMS concerts from Philadelphia stream to global audience
Text_3:
Philadelphia Chamber Music Society musicians rehearse in the American Philosophical Society's Benjamin Franklin Hall Feb. 10 2021 before their live-streamed concert. From left: pianist Gloria Chien violist Milena Pajaro-van de Stadt and clarinetist Anthony McGill. Read more

When the pandemic forced the closure of arts venues everywhere the Philadelphia Chamber Music Society (PCMS) reacted as some others did continuing to perform and setting concerts aloft on the digital wind.

The move to online though brought something unexpected to PCMS one of the nation‚Äôs busiest presenters of string quartets and piano recitalists: a new and viable business model.

Advertisement

It‚Äôs early days for online listenership and donations but in the first few months of operations PCMS‚Äôs digital enterprise has racked up some eye-popping numbers.

Viewership for the season‚Äôs first 13 events has averaged 3200 per concert. For an in-the-flesh sell-out about 350 listeners turn up to hear works of Schubert or Vivian Fung in the American Philosophical Society‚Äôs Benjamin Franklin Hall just a few steps from Independence Hall.

PCMS‚Äôs online concerts have drawn a strong local following with 63% of viewers from Pennsylvania and New Jersey. But about 20% of the audience has come from outside the United States including Canada Mexico the U.K. Germany India Israel and Japan.

Not everyone is tuning in from beginning to end. Average viewing time is just 18 minutes for the hour-plus concerts.

There‚Äôs one metric however that stands out as a marker of success. PCMS‚Äôs virtual concerts are technically free of charge but the pay-as-you-wish donation model has drawn real money ‚Äî an average of $7500 in donations per concert.

This sum is at roughly equal to the paid ticket revenue PCMS typically collected pre-pandemic at APS for a concert by a popular artist.

‚ÄúI guess I would say I am pleasantly surprised. We really had no idea how it would all pan out‚Äù says Philip Maneval PCMS‚Äôs executive director. ‚ÄúOur initial motivation was to try to put musicians back to work. They are struggling as never before. Many of them have been without almost any income since last March.‚Äù

So robust have donations been that ‚Äúthe concerts really are paying for themselves‚Äù he says.

One viewer from California new to PCMS has sent in four gifts since online concerts began. They total $5500.

This success like any other since the pandemic‚Äôs arrival must be considered a Pyrrhic victory. It was nearly a year ago that artists were suddenly idled and projects stopped cold. Survival of Philadelphia‚Äôs institutions is hardly certain. And when arts groups including PCMS return to full operations no one should forget that some familiar faces in the audience will be missing.

Still the pandemic has forced creativity and innovation. PCMS‚Äôs COVID-era concerts at APS have hosted off and on a small live audience ‚Äî up to 25. This past Wednesday afternoon Mozart rang in the hall. Clarinetist Anthony McGill violist Milena Pajaro-van de Stadt and pianist Gloria Chien could be heard rehearsing the Kegelstatt Trio for a performance with a socially distanced audience that night and the hall cleared of its normal crowd revealed a much more live acoustic.

Is there a way to renovate the hall to make this beautiful sound permanent? Let‚Äôs hope so. More immediately PCMS and APS are investing time and money in physical changes like more sophisticated cameras and lighting. The goal is a production approach and aesthetic true to PCMS fans who want a generally no-frills presentation with the focus squarely on the music.

McGill appears in another very different online approach in a Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center online show. Highly produced edited and art-directed it is more music video than pure concert film.

PCMS‚Äôs online model might not apply to other arts groups. Each organization has its own set of fixed costs union contracts and logistical hurdles that must be weighed against factors like the existence (or not) of an endowment and the depth of a donor list.

Most arts troupes though are adapting to digital life.

Opera Philadelphia has so far sold digital passes and rentals to more than 1500 households for its series of original-for-online operatic films. The Philadelphia Orchestra is selling between 1400 and 1500 tickets for its online concerts for $15 and $17 a pop ‚Äî far cheaper than the ticket price for live concerts which often hover near or above $100 each in Verizon Hall (with 2500 seats).

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs orders of magnitude less than the revenue we derive from the live concert‚Äù says orchestra president and CEO Mat√≠as Tarnopolsky. At the same time ‚Äúthe expenses have not gone down commensurately.‚Äù

For all groups now philanthropy is critical.

Hello from Brazil

PCMS has taken its share of hits during the pandemic. COVID-related travel hurdles have forced the cancellation of some of the group‚Äôs most individualistic artists like pianist Imogen Cooper. But on the plus side PCMS has folded tech into the ‚Äúsociety‚Äù part of its name by hosting chats on YouTube where listeners weigh in during the concert.

‚ÄúPeople pop in to say hello from Brazil or other people ask serious questions about the repertoire like someone who wants to know how Dvorak is perceived in the U.S. because they are in Eastern Europe‚Äù says PCMS communications director Brian Potter. ‚ÄúSome people are expressing gratitude. It‚Äôs really across the board.‚Äù

Here Google Translate is sometimes of limited help. ‚ÄúUntil recently he didn‚Äôt love the viola and then he loved it !!!‚Äù wrote one listener rather cryptically in Russian during Wednesday night‚Äôs YouTube chat as Brahms‚Äô Viola Sonata in E Flat Major Op. 120 No. 2 was being played.

Entertaining though the banter may be PCMS says it‚Äôs important to reunite listeners with the in-person concert experience. Online the sound of the piano during Wednesday evening‚Äôs concert was fine but a shadow of what it had been earlier in the day at rehearsal heard live. The Hamburg Steinway bought just before the pandemic by PCMS and its sister organization the Marlboro Music Festival might be the most lovely keyboard in the city at the moment. Listeners deserve to hear it in full.

And then there is the intangible thrill of music unmediated by an electronic scrim. ‚ÄùThe first time I went back after not hearing a live performance for a while I had tears down my face‚Äù says Maneval. ‚ÄúThe experience of hearing it live again with people around me it was such a beautiful thing.‚Äù

Although PCMS aims to continue online concerts in some capacity post-COVID-19 ‚Äúwe are doing all of this to supplement the core concept of chamber music which is to experience our concerts in person‚Äù says PCMS artistic director Miles Cohen.

Ideally in the company of a few hundred others though that could take a while.

In the meantime ‚Äúwe have 25 very enthusiastic people‚Äù says Maneval. ‚ÄúSo they clap loudly.‚Äù

The schedule of upcoming PCMS concerts is available at pcmsconcerts.org.
Name_4: Unique Turkish miniature art on display at new digital exhibition | Daily Sabah
Text_4:
Turkey's art of miniature a classical decorative craft that was recently added to the UNESCO Representative List of Intangible Cultural Heritage of Humanity will be the subject of a new exhibition that opens on Monday as part of the 360 Culture and Arts project initiated by the Directorate of Communications.

The exhibition will feature the works of the renowned Nakka≈ü Osman one of the leading ‚Äònakka≈ü‚Äô or miniaturists of the Ottoman Empire who was the chief miniaturist in the late 16th century. Osman's ‚ÄúSurname-i H√ºmayun‚Äù which are Imperial Festival Books created by artists to mark and depict in pictorial and textual detail imperial celebrations such as weddings and circumcision festivals will be displayed in the exhibition.

The exhibition will be held at Marmaray Yenikapƒ± Station in Istanbul. It will welcome visitors until March 5 and will be free of charge. The exhibition's aim is to raise awareness of and introduce to younger generations traditional arts of Turkey. It will be a digital exhibition that incorporates holographic and special projection techniques that make it possible to display the only copies of miniaturist Osman's artworks which are preserved at the Topkapƒ± Palace.

Ottoman miniature was developed over several centuries into a visual language that used to express the cultural diversity and cosmopolitan geography of the Empire. Nakka≈ü Osman was one of the leading artists of miniature during the height of the empire in the 16th century. He became to be known as the ‚ÄúLeonardo da Vinci‚Äù of the East whose unique style was visible throughout his nearly 600 art pieces.
Name_5: Google updates YouTube for iPhone first major iOS update since December
Text_5:
In context: Google has issued a bug-fixing update to its YouTube iOS app which marks the first major iOS app update since Apple's new privacy rules came into effect in December. The move comes after many speculated that Google was withholding app updates in protest over Apple's privacy "nutrition labels" in the App Store.

Following the 15.49.6 update privacy details for the YouTube app are now appearing on the App Store.

"The developer Google LLC indicated that the app's privacy practices may include handing of data as described below" the page reads. There it adds that data used to track users includes "contact info" and "identifiers" along with a wider range of data which may be linked to users' identity.

So far YouTube is the only Google app to receive an update since December. Other apps including Gmail Search and Docs received their last update before December 8 meaning they didn't have to comply with Apple's new privacy features.

Apple is hoping to equip users with a better understanding of how their personal data is being used and to allow iPhone and iPad owners to opt-out of tracking on a per-app basis.

The news didn't go down well with ad firms or social media giant Facebook which went so far as to take out two full-page newspaper ads slamming Apple's privacy policies and claiming that such a move would be "devastating for small businesses." Critics were quick to question Facebook's motives however given the company's history of questionable privacy practices.

For iPhone and iPad users the good news is that we should expect to see further Google apps receive bug-fixing updates in the coming days and weeks. Like we said YouTube's latest update is available to download now on the App Store.

Name: Eli Lilly and Company
Name_1: I'm an Amazon Shopping Editor and These Are My Favorite Products for Long Smooth and Thick Hair
Text_1:
Getty Images

It's taken me a long time to find a hair routine that works. I've tried every product and hack you can think of to keep my hair free of oil frizz and tangles. On top of that I don't have super thick hair so I'm always trying to pump up the volume. It's hard to find products that tackle everything I want without weighing my hair down but I've finally found my holy grail routine ‚Äî and it only costs $37 on Amazon.

Whether you have long and limp hair you're trying to grow your hair out or you're constantly fighting with knots these four hair products might end your battles once and for all.

Honeydew Biotin Shampoo

I've already raved about this shampoo but it's so good that I can't stop talking about it. This is the shampoo that has not only helped me grow out my hair over the past year but has kept it healthy and thick too. The shampoo is made with biotin keratin and zinc which work together to support hair growth and strengthen strands. It's also made with tea tree and rosemary oils which are great for my oily scalp and removing product buildup. I always air dry my hair which could go awry if I use the wrong shampoo but the Honeydew Biotin Shampoo always leaves it voluminous and smooth.

Shop now: $12; amazon.com

L'Or√©al Paris 8 Second Wonder Water

I have to admit I was scared to use this. Anything that advertises silky hair with no weigh-down usually leaves me with greasy strands ‚Äî but not this time. I'm so relieved to have found a weekly hair treatment that actually makes my hair super soft and shiny. L'Or√©al's 8 Second Wonder Water is made with amino acids and proteins that smooth the hair's surface. Plus since I've been using it my hair is much easier to brush through. My favorite part (other than its amazing scent) is that you only have to leave it in for eight seconds before rinsing it out.

Recently I've also been using the Dream Lengths Wonder Water which is made specifically for long hair and I love it just as much.

Shop now: $9; amazon.com

Wet Brush Shine Enhancer Brush

We've all heard of Wet Brush but I was super intrigued by this shine-enhancing version that's made with boar bristles. Since my hair is longer than ever now brushing out tangles has been a pain in the you-know-what. I had been using Tangle Teezer's brush which was fine but not the best option for my difficult knots. This Wet Brush on the other hand makes brushing my hair a breeze plus it always leaves a pretty sheen.

Shop now: $10; amazon.com

L'Or√©al Paris Dream Lengths No Haircut Cream

When I saw the name of this product I knew it was meant for me. Over the last year I've only gotten one trim so I'm trying to do what I can to upkeep my hair without visiting the salon. The No Haircut Cream has been a great supplement to my routine ‚Äî it smooths out my ends and makes my hair look blow-dried (even though I'm too lazy to actually do that). It's made with castor oil and vitamins and it offers heat protection up to 450 degrees Fahrenheit if you do opt for heat styling.

Shop now: $6; amazon.com

Name: Entergy
Name_1: John Richard Pickens Obituary
Text_1:
John Richard (Dick) Pickens 81 of Jonesboro passed away on Thursday February 11 2021. He was born on December 20 1939 to the late O.C. Pickens Jr. and Catherine Blanton Pickens in Strawberry Ark. Dick grew up in Jonesboro and graduated from Jonesboro High School in 1958 where he excelled in basketball. He was a member of the 1956 State Champion Basketball Team and was named All-American in 1958. He continued his basketball career in college at Arkansas State University and finished at the University of Arkansas-Monticello where he met the love of his life Paula his biggest supporter and cheerleader on and off the basketball court. After graduating in 1966 he began his 36-year career in El Dorado with Arkansas Power & Light now known as Entergy. His career led him to several residences including Blytheville Kennett and Walnut Ridge. Upon retirement he and Paula moved back to his hometown of Jonesboro to be near his parents children and grandchildren. He and Paula loved tailgating and attending Razorback games with their many friends. Dick was a prankster known for his infectious laugh and jokes. He never met a stranger and found the fun in every situation. He loved playing the game of golf. He was a proud grandfather always cheering on his grandchildren in all of their sporting events. In addition to his parents he was preceded in death by his brother Jim his nephew Steve McDaniel and brother-in-law Larry McDaniel. He is survived by his wife of 55 years Paula (Johnson) Pickens one daughter: Karen (Mark) Jones identical twin sons Paul (Laura) Pickens and John Pickens all of Jonesboro. He is also survived by one sister Cathy McDaniel of Paragould; sister-in-law Sue Pickens of Little Rock; as well as many nieces and nephews. His legacy will continue with his seven grandchildren: Danny Salazar of Blytheville Trent Jones of Naples Fla. Matthew (Morgan) Jones Spencer Jones Caroline Pickens John Paul Pickens and Luke Pickens all of Jonesboro. His grandchildren will also serve as their Bobbo's pallbearers. Visitation will take place on Sunday February 14 from 1 p.m. to 2 p.m. at Emerson Funeral Home immediately followed by the funeral service officiated by Chris Harrell. In lieu of flowers the family requests that donations be made to St. Bernards Foundation St. Jude Children's Research Hospital or a charity of your choice.

Published February 14 2021

Name: Equifax
Name_1: Why peer lending and savings groups persist ‚Äî especially in a pandemic
Text_1:
Cost of Living 9:24 Saving circles are gaining ground in Canada and FinTech firms are taking notice

Mixing friendship and finance can be messy but for many Canadians who take advantage of peer lending and savings it works.

The concept involves groups of friends or acquaintances pooling money together to provide funding in situations where traditional financial institutions won't or don't work.

Rahma Mohamed who lives in Edmonton started participating in groups like this ‚Äî called hagbads in her Somali community ‚Äî once she was old enough to start working.

For 10 months at a time she and about a dozen other women would agree to save together contributing equal amounts every month and taking turns withdrawing largers sums made up of everyone's contributions. The system was based on trust: a newcomer to the group could not withdraw right away but only after a history of making payments.

The Cost of Living ‚ù§s money ‚Äî how it makes (or breaks) us.

Catch us Sundays on CBC Radio One at 12:00 p.m. (12:30 p.m. NT).

We also repeat the following Tuesday at 11:30 a.m. in most provinces.

Thanks to these groups Mohamed said she saved enough to pay off nearly $30000 in student loans within three years of graduating from university.

Beyond giving her a social structure to save she said the groups helped strengthen friendships and community ties as women confided in each other and worked together toward achieving their goals.

"It feels almost like people are paying into your dream even though it's your own money that you're getting at the end" she said.

Academics call groups like this rotating savings and credit associations but they are known by many different names in Canada and around the world.

Canadians often use peer lending groups as an alternative to more traditional banking. (Chris Helgren/Reuters)

"It's very interesting and a relatively simple mechanism for allowing small amounts of money to be accumulated within a group that has group responsibility and also has regular agreed-upon payout schedules" said Susanna Khavul a professor in the Lucas College and Graduate School of Business at San Jose State University.

For Canadians who face barriers to traditional banking and other forms of credit these groups have long served an important purpose by providing access to capital they wouldn't otherwise have.

Now alongside the COVID-19 pandemic peer lending ‚Äî in many forms ‚Äî is becoming more mainstream as some groups move online entrepreneurs seek alternative funding sources and tech companies design platforms to cash in on these valuable peer networks.

Moving rotational savings online

On Prince Edward Island startup MICC Financial is digitizing the rotating savings concept.

Co-founder and CEO Jonah Chininga said he was inspired to develop a savings app after struggling as an international student to access and build credit in Canada.

James Muhato left Jonah Chininga Sergio Fernandez and Daniel Ohaegbu all had a hand in creating the MICC Financial app. (Reddin Handrahan)

Through Chininga's app groups of three to twelve users link their bank accounts and make monthly payments. The app operates like a rotating savings and credit association but with a twist: since the company sends transaction data to credit bureaus users also build credit and pay a small monthly fee to use the service.

Launched in September the app is seeing its highest engagement from young people and young entrepreneurs who have struggled during the pandemic.

"It has really shown where the gaps are within the financial system here in Canada in terms of accessing credit especially" Chininga said.

Non-profit lending circles expand as well

Non-profit organizations have also embraced the peer-lending concept and seen demand for it increase during the pandemic.

The PARO Centre for Women's Enterprise a non-profit social enterprise based in Thunder Bay Ont. runs more than 185 peer lending circles in that province.

As small businesses struggled with pandemic-related restrictions and closures the organization saw unprecedented demand for its lending circles.

Don't feel like waiting for your dose of The Cost of Living on Sundays?

To listen anytime click here to download the show to your podcast player of choice.

Subscribe to get episodes automatically downloaded to your device.

"Women started calling us from all over the province even if it wasn't where we were normally working because they were really struggling and they didn't fit into the criteria for federal programs to be able to keep their business going" said Rosalind Lockyer the PARO Centre's founder and CEO.

The circles and the training sessions linked to them have moved online. The digital format is allowing the non-profit to serve more women than in the past.

Peer-to-peer lending as a business

Canadian peer-to-peer (P2P) lending platforms such as Lending Loop and goPeer connect borrowers with lenders claiming to be faster and more accessible than large banks and financial institutions.

Though the industry is less established in Canada P2P lending has seen increasing popularity over the past decade in other countries including the United States and United Kingdom.

Investors began to make huge investments in these American and British platforms ‚Ä¶ they are much less personal now and they are much more seen as kind of a big business. - Rob Aitken author of

"What interests me the most is actually the link between these very small fringe banking and financial practices in the larger financial markets because they're actually deeply connected" said Rob Aitken a professor of political science at the University of Alberta and author of the book Fringe Finance: Crossing and Contesting the Borders of Global Capital.

Though P2P platforms might have been intended for individual borrowers and lenders according to Aitken they also end up attracting large institutional investors.

"Investors began to make huge investments in these American and British platforms and it's changed the dynamic there quite a bit so that they are much less personal now and they are much more seen as kind of a big business" Aitken said.

But whether online or offline Susanna Khavul predicts peer lending and savings groups will always be around in some form because they serve a social purpose in addition to a financial one.

"I'm not going to bet against humans wanting connections with other humans" she said.

Written and produced by Madeleine Cummings.

Click "listen" at the top of the page to hear this segment or download the Cost of Living podcast.

The Cost of Living airs every week on CBC Radio One Sundays at 12:00 p.m. (12:30 NT).

Name: Etsy
Name_1: Mila Kunis and Ashton Kutcher Spent a Surprisingly Low Amount on Their Wedding Bands
Text_1:
Mila Kunis and Ashton Kutcher got married in 2015 and spent a ridiculously low sum -- at least by Hollywood standards -- on their wedding bands.

Celebrity engagement rings often come with hefty price tags. They can cost thousands or even millions of dollars. But in the case of Mila Kunis and Ashton Kutcher they‚Äôre a rare Hollywood couple who sport more affordable wedding rings.

Mila Kunis and Ashton Kutcher married in 2015

Ashton Kutcher and Mila Kunis | Jesse Grant/Getty Images

Kutcher and Kunis became husband and wife in July 2015. They didn‚Äôt have an elaborate celebration with a star-studded guest list but rather a private affair. As Kutcher said during a 2016 appearance on The Ellen DeGeneres Show they went to great lengths to keep the ceremony a secret.

‚ÄúIt was a ninja effort‚Äù Kutcher said. ‚ÄúWe really didn‚Äôt want helicopters [with paparazzi photographers] at our wedding and it‚Äôs a legitimate concern.‚Äù

The Ranch star continued saying he even left false clues online.

‚ÄúI was posting things on social media that were in different locations to avoid the helicopters because we didn‚Äôt want to be screaming our vows at each other and be like ‚ÄòForever!‚Äô ‚ÄòDid you say never?‚Äô We didn‚Äôt want to do that thing so we went really under the radar with it‚Äù he explained.

After saying their I do‚Äôs the couple took an RV trip with their then-10-month-old daughter Wyatt and Kutcher‚Äôs parents. As Kunis revealed later on The Tonight Show Starring Jimmy Fallon the trip was a disaster.

‚ÄúIf you‚Äôve ever seen the National Lampoon movies our honeymoon was like a real-life National Lampoon‚Äòs honeymoon‚Äù she said.

Mila Kunis bought her and Ashton Kutcher‚Äôs wedding bands on Etsy

After pricing out rings Kunis headed to Etsy to get wedding bands for her and Kutcher.

‚ÄúI wanted the thinnest possible platinum band‚Äù she said during a 2016 appearance on Conan. ‚ÄúI mean you can‚Äôt see it but it‚Äôs super super thin. I looked at how much Tiffany‚Äôs [cost] and I was like ‚ÄòThey‚Äôre how much? This is astronomical.‚Äô So I went on Etsy and I was like ‚Äò$90?‚Äô I was like ‚ÄòBuy now!‚Äô $90 everybody! Ashton‚Äôs was $100 so technically his wedding band was a little bit more expensive than mine.‚Äù

The Bad Moms actor continued saying she has a ‚Äúbeautiful‚Äù engagement ring from Kutcher she never wears. Instead she wears her more affordable ring.

Ashton Kutcher and Mila Kunis: Who has the higher net worth?

Kutcher and Kunis are both successful actors but they didn‚Äôt grow up with money. Hence their more frugal ways as adults. Both have been open about their upbringings saying they didn‚Äôt have much money. As parents it‚Äôs important to them they don‚Äôt raise their children to feel entitled.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs so important because we both came from pretty solid poverty backgrounds and grew up very poor and are very much self-made and are very aware of what a dollar is worth‚Äù Kunis said of her and Kutcher on the The Kyle and Jackie O Show per CBS News. ‚ÄúNothing‚Äôs been handed to us.‚Äù

They met on That ‚Äô70s Show as teens and even played love interests. In fact Kunis shared her first kiss ‚Äî a scripted one for the comedy ‚Äî with her future husband. They were both established actors when they reconnected at the 2012 Golden Globe Awards. Kutcher had multiple TV and film roles and Kunis had starred in Black Swan only two years earlier.

Kutcher‚Äôs worth a reported $200 million while Kunis has an estimated net worth of $75 million according to Celebrity Net Worth. But the couple doesn‚Äôt plan on leaving all of their money to their children. The actors want to invent in their kids‚Äô business ideas and donate the rest.
Name_2: Sellers Choice Awards 2021: Merchants Rate Top Online Marketplaces
Text_2:
Welcome to the 12th annual EcommerceBytes Sellers Choice Awards. Each year we invite sellers to rate and review the marketplaces on which they sell and they use the opportunity to tell companies (and each other) what‚Äôs working and what isn‚Äôt.

As in past years we let readers nominate their top choices and then opened up the voting to the top 10 nominated venues.

Readers rated the finalists in four key areas ‚Äì profitability customer service communication and ease of use. Respondents were also asked how likely they were to recommend each marketplace as a selling venue to a friend or colleague.

As they do every year sellers pointed to specific policies and practices that affected them.

There was great diversity of sellers responding. Some were newbies or low-volume; others noted they were longtime pros. Some were artisans and some used fulfillment services.

The Results



eBay again topped the list this year overall followed by Bonanza and Ruby Lane. The rankings take into account four key criteria ‚Äì profitability customer service communication and ease of use.

Coming in fourth place was Etsy followed by Mercari and Poshmark. Amazon narrowly squeaked ahead of eCrater with Craigslist and Facebook coming in ninth and tenth place respectively.

eBay took the top spot for Profitability again this year and it also placed first in Ease of use. Bonanza took top spots for Customer Service and Communication and it also was the top most recommended marketplace.

With more people shopping online due to the coronavirus ecommerce should have been the rising tide that lifted all boats in 2020. But there were fewer outright mentions of the effects of COVID-19 than we had expected.

Some sellers noted that they had benefitted from extra traffic to marketplaces but it also left them vulnerable to claims of late delivery especially during the holiday shopping period when some marketplaces decided the fate of Item Not Received claims. Despite getting packages into the mail on time it was the seller not the carrier that ended up taking losses when items weren‚Äôt delivered on time some sellers said.

The top nominated venues were diverse from traditional marketplaces like eBay and Amazon; to niche sites; to classifieds site Craigslist; to social platforms like Facebook. Some of the finalists were large publicly traded companies; others were tiny versions.

In reading through sellers reviews we picked up on three attitudes towards marketplaces. First there were the venues where sellers could list with little investment in time or money and what sales they got were quite satisfactory. Those were the ‚Äúit is what it is‚Äù venues.

Then there were the ‚Äúmega platforms‚Äù where some sellers were quite satisfied due to the volume of sales but others bristled due to a feeling that the companies had stacked the deck against the sellers. It went beyond the typical complaints of ‚Äúnickle-and-diming‚Äù fees to practices such as charging a commission fee on shipping and sales tax which sellers felt were wrong.

And then there were marketplaces where sellers felt at home and enjoyed selling but yearned for more traffic and sales. Those venues offered autonomy or an attractive fee structure and sellers urged those venues to advertise more to fulfill their potential.

You can read more about these issues in the individual findings for each marketplace. Next up ‚Äì rankings and how they break down.

How It Breaks Down ‚Äì Profitability

We asked sellers ‚ÄúHow would you rate your profitability as a seller on (marketplace name)?‚Äù eBay topped the list for Profitability followed by Etsy Mercari Craigslist and Facebook.

How It Breaks Down ‚Äì Customer Service

We asked sellers ‚ÄúHow would you rate the customer service (marketplace name) provides to sellers?‚Äù Bonanza topped the list for Customer Service followed by Ruby Lane eBay Etsy and Poshmark.

How It Breaks Down ‚Äì Communication

We asked sellers ‚ÄúHow would you rate (marketplace name)‚Äôs communication with you as a seller?‚Äù Bonanza topped the list for Communication followed by Ruby Lane eBay Poshmark and Etsy.

How It Breaks Down ‚Äì Ease of Use

We asked sellers ‚ÄúHow would you rate (marketplace name)‚Äôs ease of use as a seller?‚Äù eBay topped the list for Ease of Use followed by Bonanza Etsy Mercari and Craigslist.

How It Breaks Down ‚Äì Recommended Selling Venue

We asked sellers ‚ÄúHow likely are you to recommend (marketplace name) as a Selling venue to a friend or colleague? Bonanza scored highest on Recommended Selling Venue followed by Mercari Etsy eBay and Ruby Lane.

Comments: Insider Information

With thousands of responses it‚Äôs impossible to include every comment each marketplace received but we include the most representative comments and the ones most interesting or useful to readers. Note that the number of comments left for a marketplace doesn‚Äôt necessarily indicate its placement in the rankings

Comments are included on the individual marketplace rating pages.

Individual Online Marketplace Ratings

You can find each marketplace with the results of the Sellers Choice survey on the following pages.

Page 1 Sellers Choice Marketplace Ratings: eBay

Page 2 Sellers Choice Marketplace Ratings: Bonanza

Page 3 Sellers Choice Marketplace Ratings: Ruby Lane

Page 4 Sellers Choice Marketplace Ratings: Etsy

Page 5 Sellers Choice Marketplace Ratings: Mercari

Page 6 Sellers Choice Marketplace Ratings: Poshmark

Page 7 Sellers Choice Marketplace Ratings: Amazon

Page 8 Sellers Choice Marketplace Ratings: eCrater

Page 9 Sellers Choice Marketplace Ratings: Craigslist

Name_3: 11 of the best 'Sex and the City' merch or products inspired by SATC
Text_3:
Looking for more of the best deals sales and product recommendations? Sign up for Yahoo Lifestyle Canada‚Äôs newsletter!

Whether you consider yourself a Charlotte Carrie Miranda or Samantha there's a product here for you. (Image via Getty Images)

Yahoo Lifestyle Canada is committed to finding you the best products at the best prices. We may receive a share from purchases made via links on this page. Pricing and availability are subject to change.

It's been more than 20 years since we first met Carrie Bradshaw Samantha Jones Charlotte York and Miranda Hobbes ‚Äî and we couldn't help but wonder will we ever meet again? The answer is yes because there is a "Sex and the City" revival in the works titled "And Just Like That."

Samantha Jones played by Canadian actress Kim Cattrall will be noticeably absent from the new series but that could give the series a chance to hire some diverse cast members. It will be interesting to see how they explain Samantha's absence but it also gives the writers a chance to fix some of the things they got wrong in the '90s especially since it's airing in a post #MeToo world.

There are so many different possibilities in store for the new series and fans cannot wait to hear more details about a 21st-century "SATC".

If re-watching two movies and six seasons of the original HBO series isn't enough here are 11 "Sex and the City"-inspired products that will keep you patiently waiting for the revival premiere.

Custom Carrie Name Necklace. (Image via Etsy)

The Carrie Necklace was an unforgettable part of the "Sex and the City" franchise. Sarah Jessica Parker wore the necklace for years and when she lost the gold chain while living in Paris with Aleksandr Petrovsky it was just pointing to the fact that their relationship was doomed.

This custom Carrie name necklace from Etsy can be personalized with your own name or you can use Carrie's for all the "SATC" feels.

SHOP IT: Etsy $36 (originally $45)

'Sex & the City' Gals Zipper Pouch. (Image via Redbubble)

Even though Kim Cattrall won't be joining the "SATC" revival it doesn't mean we have to forget about the times when the whole gang was together. Keep that memory alive with this zipper pouch from Redbubble. It's available in three sizes and you can fill it with makeup or use it as a pencil case.

SHOP IT: Redbubble from $12

Carrie Bradshaw Shirt - Sex and the City Quotes Tee - 2000's T-shirt. (Image via Etsy)

Let Carrie Bradshaw remind you that you don't have time for idiots with this cute T-shirt from Etsy.

SHOP IT: Etsy $30

Sex and the City- Berger Sticky Note Breakup Sticker. (Image via Etsy)

Carrie and Jack Berger had a relationship full of ups and downs but remember when he broke up with her on a Post-It note? Well now you never have to forget with this infamous breakup sticker.

SHOP IT: Redbubble $3

'Sex and the City' Birthday Banner. (Image via Etsy)

Celebrate any birthday or bachelorette party with Carrie Bradshaw Charlotte York Miranda Hobbes Samantha Jones Mr. Big Aidan Shaw and Stanford Blatch all in the same room. This banner from Etsy is a digital download so you can print the banner over and over again for any occasion.

SHOP IT: Etsy from $12

Click here to sign up for Yahoo Canada's lifestyle newsletter.

Sex And The City "Samantha Jones vs. The People" Adjustable Cloth Face Mask Covering. (Image via Etsy)

Samantha said what we were all thinking in the pre-COVID days. Yes there were people everywhere at work on the subway in restaurants but now there is like... no one around? Face masks are not going anywhere soon and this one is a great addition to your collection. This is a reusable cloth face mask that has two layers o fabric and elastic ear loops. This mask isn't medical-grade so make sure you're only wearing it for fun and not full protection.

SHOP IT: Etsy $16

I Couldn‚Äôt Help But Wonder - Sex And The City - Print (Image via Etsy)

When people think about "Sex and the City" they hear the catchy theme song or a long monologue from Carrie Bradshaw sitting at her first edition MacBook ending with the phrase that began with "I couldn't help but wonder." This graphic print will help you wonder every single day.

SHOP IT: Etsy from $22

Rooftop Drinks Throw Pillow. (Image via Redbubble)

This throw pillow with a throwback photo of the cast having a drink is the perfect gift for your SATC-obsessed friend. Toss this pillow on the couch while you re-watch all of the seasons ahead of the revival premiere.

SHOP IT: Redbubble $27

Sex and The City Babes Coffee Mug. (Image via Etsy)

Have your morning cup of coffee with Miranda Samantha Charlotte and Carrie. This hand-printed white ceramic mug uses an original watercolour illustration of the iconic group of women.

SHOP IT: Etsy $17

Sex And The City Print. (Image via Etsy)

Here is your daily reminder to be fashionable like Carrie wise like Miranda kind like Charlotte and fierce like Samantha. Hang this print in any room and give yourself a pep talk before you take on the day.

SHOP IT: Etsy from $7

Love Keychain with a sparkle. (Image via Etsy)

Remember when Carrie hired Lousie played by Jennifer Hudson as a personal assistant because she needed to organize all her wedding gifts? Lousie from St.Louis moved to New York City to fall in love and she carried around a golden key chain that spells out "love." Channel your inner Lousie with this sparkly gold keychain.

SHOP IT: Etsy $15

Let us know what you think by commenting below and tweeting @YahooStyleCA! Follow us on Twitter and Instagram and sign up for our newsletter.
Name_4: Affordable Alternatives To Murano Glass Mushroom Lamps
Text_4:
I'll be honest: I'm a sucker for an Instagram trend. I'm the easiest person to get on board with a hyped up piece of clothing a beauty product or an interiors buy. I'm basically an influencer's dream. And the latest thing to catch my eye is the Murano glass lamp which is shaped like a cute little mushroom. Problem is one of these will set you back literally hundreds of pounds which is why I went looking for glass lamps that are dupes for a Murano.

The real Murano lamps you can find out there are mostly vintage and let me tell you they're certainly not cheap. I'm talking prices that start at ¬£300-¬£500 and go right up to the thousand quid mark. For a lamp. Now unless you're a bajillionaire I'm guessing you (like I) do not have that kind of money to spend. But all those Instagram content creators with the coolest style and homes are likely still taunting you with this glass lamp.

Luckily there are several dupes out there. The best one I've found is by Urban Outfitters; their Ansel lamp comes in three designs which currently are all sadly out of stock.

I ummed and aahed over buying one when they were available for days and now deeply regret my decision not to go for it. I've contacted the team at UO to see if we can expect it to come back and will keep you updated.

Read more about that one along with some other options below. Most still don't come super cheap but they're still a hell of a lot more affordable than the OGs.
Name_5: How to Turn Your Hobby Into a Career
Text_5:
A FedEx driver hand-crafting soaps. A hairstylist hawking porkless bao buns. A restaurant manager repurposing denim jackets.

The dream of turning a hobby into a Plan B career is almost a clich√© of the gig economy with countless tips published on selling vintage comic books brewing beer playing video games and even telling jokes.

After a year scarred by the coronavirus pandemic however in which millions of Americans lost their jobs it‚Äôs starting to look more like a necessity than a fantasy particularly for people who have been laid off or forced to step away from jobs to tend remote-schooled children.

Yelp recorded nearly 100000 business closures during the first eight months of 2020 but also a 10 percent rise in new businesses selling cupcakes doughnuts cakes macarons and other desserts. Etsy saw a 42 percent spike in new sellers in the third quarter of 2020 when compared with the year before.
